Sudan has extended its curfew for two weeks in an effort to curb the spread of the Covid-19 pandemic. The Security and Defence Council approved the extension of the curfew in the capital Khartoum until June 18. But it allowed for more movement in the city from 6am to 3pm on condition that residents adhere to safety and health regulations.||targeted pop group: No|non compliance: Up to detention

Sudan extends the closure of airports for international and domestic passenger flights until 12 July 2020. OCHA_comments: Lockdown in Khartoum State extended to 7 July: Authorities have announced that the lockdown in Khartoum state has been extended until 7 July with a curfew from 0600 to 1500. Starting 8 July there will be a gradual return to work for specific institutions in coordination with the Ministry of Health and movement will be allowed from 0500 to 1800.

schools in most states will open for grade 8 testing next week. Grade eight examinations to commence in mid-July: Last week six states (West Darfur, Khartoum, Kassala, Gedaref, White Nile, West Kordofan) announced that the grade eight examinations will take place from 12-17 July for five to eight days. Another five states (El Gezira, River Nile, Northern, Sennar and Central Darfur) completed the grade eight examinations before schools closed in March before schools closed. Grade eight exams are the responsibility of the state, while grade 11 exams (to secondary school) is a national responsibility.
